views.html:
• SCTE/ISBE: Network Architecture
  • Arris: Fiber Deep Architecture
  • Arris: Aging Plant Overview
views.description: Learn about the headend, the outside plant, and the customer premises.
views.title: HFC Network Overview

views.description: The node is the interface between the fiberoptic cable and the hardline cable in a HFC network. The node is an active device, meaning that it requires power from a power supply, inserted into the node by the power inserter.
views.title: Powered Node

views.description: The description should come from gearList2.json Node.description
views.title: Node

views.description: The description should come from gearList2.json DropCable.description
views.title: Drop Cable

views.description: In this view we see the location of the tap and two mid-span drop cables. The mid-span attachments avoid trespassing aerially over the property of the subscriber's neighbor.
views.title: Avoid Aerial Trespass - Front
Midspan Attachment Point to House Attachment Point
House Attachment Point to House Box

gearList.html: The 180 Degree Adapter helps to connect the hardline to devices when working in tight spaces.
gearList.description: Provides a right-angle connector for hardline cable.
gearList.title: 180 Degree Adapter
gearList.name: _180_Degree_Adapter

gearList.html: Available in different lengths.
gearList.description: Connects hardline cable to devices when working in tight spaces.
gearList.title: 180 Degree Socket Adapter
gearList.name: _180_Degree_Socket_Adapter

gearList.description: Combines the channel output signals of the video and audio devices and adds program-specific information.
gearList.title: Active Combiner
gearList.name: Active_Combiner

gearList.description: Secures the drop to the span in a way that allows for expansion.
gearList.title: Aerial Drop Clamp
gearList.name: Aerial_Drop_Clamp

gearList.html:
The goal of amplifiers is to maintain unity gain across the coaxial plant. Amplifiers are found on the express cable (trunk); bridge the RF onto multiple legs (bridger and mini-bridger), and extend the signal to end-of-line (EOL) customers (line extenders). Learn more...
  • How does an amp work?
  • Try it! Relate design to operation.
  • Trunk and Bridger Amps from DFC
  • Line Extenders from DFC
gearList.description: Rebuilds the original RF signal from the node, correcting RF signal degradation caused by transport through the hardline cable. Combines and amplifies carriers on the return and transmits them to the node.
gearList.title: Amplifier
gearList.name: Amplifier

gearList.html: The amplifier module is easily replaced in the event of damage or failure
gearList.description: Houses the active electronics inside the amplifier case.
gearList.title: Amplifier Module
gearList.name: Amplifier_Module

gearList.html: The barrel connector is a splice, built with a brass insert to connect the center conductors together and a dielectric.
gearList.description: Provides the physical interface for the short cable connecting to the DVR, MOCA Node, DTA, or Cable Modem.
gearList.title: Barrel Connector
gearList.name: Barrel_Connector

gearList.html: Amplifies the downstream and allows the upstream to pass. The amplifier is installed inside and powered using an AC/DC power block. Power runs over the coax inside wire.
gearList.description: Amplifies the downstream RF energy to meet specified signal levels in order to operate the CPE.
gearList.title: Bi-Directional Amplifier
gearList.name: Bi-Directional_Amplifier

gearList.html: Bonding blocks are sometimes still called "ground blocks." The block acts as a test point and protects the OSP and the customer's equipment.
gearList.description: Provides the interface between the drop and the customer's inside wire and bonds to the building grounding system to protect against shock and damage from electrical surges.
gearList.title: Bonding Block
gearList.name: Bonding_Block

gearList.html: The bonding clamp is designed to minimize electrolytic corrosion caused by bonding copper to steel. It is essential for electrical safety.
gearList.description: Clamps the building wire to the strand.
gearList.title: Bonding Clamp
gearList.name: Bonding_Clamp

gearList.html: Bonding to ground is a critical element of all subscriber installations.
gearList.description: Carries excess voltage to the building's ground system. Bonding wire is designed to carry voltage from surges like lightning.
gearList.title: Bonding Wire
gearList.name: Bonding_Wire

gearList.html: Building wire is also called riser bond and is available in large gauge 4AWG and 8AWG. Building wire is clamped to the strand and run through the riser to a ground rod at the base of the pole.
gearList.description: Bonds the strand to a ground rod to protect the devices and technicians from electrical shock.
gearList.title: Building Wire
gearList.name: Building_Wire

gearList.html:
Learn more about cable modems and gateways (includes telephone jacks)
  • Arris Cable Modem and Gateway Quick-Start guides
  • What is the IoT?
  • How do Internet cameras work?
  • What is WiFi?
  • What are WiFi boosters, repeaters, and extenders?
  • What's new in WiFi?
  • How can I troubleshoot my Internet connection?
  • How can I change the settings on the cable modem?
gearList.description: Provides high-speed Internet services using DOCSIS.
gearList.title: Cable Modem
gearList.name: Cable_Modem

gearList.html: Also called a TV Wall Plate, the faceplate includes a barrel connector, threaded at both ends.
gearList.description: Demarcs the inside wire at the wall.
gearList.title: CATV Wall Outlet
gearList.name: CATV_Wall_Outlet

gearList.html:
Learn more about CCAP/CMTS...
  • Discover the role of the headend and hub
  • SCTE's IP Engineering Professional course
  • CCAP and the headend
gearList.description: The Converged Cable Access Platform (CCAP)/Cable Modem Termination System (CMTS) control the modulation and demodulation of digital RF carriers.
gearList.title: CCAP/CMTS
gearList.name: CCAP_CMTS

gearList.html: The device is commonly called a "Cherry Picker" because it picks and organizes the program streams into the channel lineup.
gearList.description: Assembles and interleaves the MPEG2 transport streams into each of the digital carriers.
gearList.title: Cherry Picker/MUX
gearList.name: Cherry_Picker_MUX

gearList.html: Compression connectors used outside often have rubber grommets to provide a watertight seal. The compression fitting is designed to secure the cable's sheath without deforming the dielectric foam insulation.
gearList.description: Connects drop cable and inside wire to bonding blocks, splitters, and equipment.
gearList.title: Compression F-Connector
gearList.name: Compression_F-Connector

gearList.html: Connects to an AC/DC power block.
gearList.description: Injects DC to power a bi-directional amplifier.
gearList.title: DC Power Inserter
gearList.name: DC_Power_Inserter

gearList.html: The demodulator's baseband output can be SD or HD. The output signal is inserted into the multiplexer through the router.
gearList.description: Converts video and audio RF signals to baseband.
gearList.title: Demodulator
gearList.name: Demodulator

gearList.html: With a coaxial input, the DTA processes the digital data to output HDMI (HD models), Composite, or IF Baseband (Channel 3/4).
gearList.description: The Digital Terminal Adapter (DTA) decodes the digital programming so it can be displayed on a TV.
gearList.title: Digital Terminal Adapter
gearList.name: Digital_Terminal_Adapter

gearList.html: A DVR, also called a Digital Video Recorder, receives a channel guide which is loaded on the box. It also transmits status messages to a set top box monitoring server.
gearList.description: The Digital Video Recorder (DVR)Decodes the digital audio and video for display on a TV. Also records and stores the programming for playback at a later time.
gearList.title: Digital Video Recorder
gearList.name: Digital_Video_Recorder

gearList.html: Also called a network interface unit (NIU), network interface device (NID), and house box, the enclosure protects the bonding block, connectors, and /or splitters from the elements.
gearList.description: Houses the physical interface between the fiber drop and the customer's inside wire.
gearList.title: Fiber Demarcation Enclosure
gearList.name: Fiber_Demarcation_Enclosure

gearList.html:
Learn about drop cables...
  • Fiberoptic drop cables from FS
  • Coaxial drop cable from Commscope
gearList.description: Transports the signals for voice, video, and data between the tap and the demarc. In RF demarcs the drop cable is coaxial (RG6 or RG11) and runs from the tap to the demarc. In FTTH demarcs, the drop cable is low count fiber and a short RG6 drop is used inside the demarc between the ONU and the inside wire. Drop cables are identified by drop tags.
gearList.title: Drop Cable
gearList.name: Drop_Cable

gearList.html: Drop tags come in different colors to identify the type of drop and the customer it serves.
gearList.description: Identifies the assigned subscriber and service status [active/disconnected/filtered] for the tagged drop cable.
gearList.title: Drop Tag
gearList.name: Drop_Tag

gearList.html: Also referred to as a mid-span clamp, the E Span Clamp is one of a number of clamps used to secure the drop cable to the strand and position it away from driveways and property lines.
gearList.description: Secures the drop along the span.
gearList.title: E Span Clamp
gearList.name: E_Span_Clamp

gearList.html: The EAS antenna is mounted outdoors.
gearList.description: Receives the EAS public safety broadcasts that activate the EAS system in the headend.
gearList.title: Emergency Alert System (EAS) Antenna
gearList.name: Emergency_Alert_System_EAS_Antenna

gearList.html: The EAS antenna is mounted outdoors.
gearList.description: Activates upon receipt of an EAS broadcast and interrupts all transport streams and inserts the audio and text message.
gearList.title: Emergency Alert System (EAS) Controller
gearList.name: Emergency_Alert_System_EAS_Controller

gearList.html: Equalizer modules vary in form factor depending on the vendor and model of the amplifier.
gearList.description: Adjusts the gain in the lower, middle, and upper frequency bands in amplifiers.
gearList.title: Equalizer
gearList.name: Equalizer

gearList.html:
The fiber-to-the-home (FTTH) demarc is a weather-resistant enclosure that houses the components used to connect the OSP to the customers inside wire. The drop is fiberoptic cable. In an RFoG Demarc, a mini-node optical network unit (ONU) converts light to RF (downstream) and RF to light (upstream).
  • Check out this RFoG enclosure from Alpha
  • RFoG explained
gearList.description: Houses the components used to interface the fiber drop to the customer's inside wire.
gearList.title: FTTH Demarc
gearList.name: FTTH_Demarc

gearList.html:
Find out more about Mux/Demux units...
  • Commscope Dual LGX Module Wavelength Division Multiplexer
  • Commscope FTTX Brightpath Solutions
gearList.description: Combines (Mux) multiple optical signals onto a single fiber. Breaks out (Demux) multiple optical signals from a single fiber.
gearList.title: Fiber Mux/Demux
gearList.name: Fiber_Mux_Demux

gearList.description: Cross connects optical devices such as ONUs, ONTs, and nodes to the correct fiber or wavelength associated with that device.
gearList.title: Fiber Patch Panel
gearList.name: Fiber_Patch_Panel

gearList.html:
Unterminated fiber needs a pigtail spliced onto it. Learn more...
  • Types of connectors - APC vs. UPC
  • A great view of an SC-APC pigtail from European supplier Dipol
gearList.description: Provides a connector to insert into the optical network unit (ONU). The pigtail is spliced onto the fiberoptic drop cable.
gearList.title: Fiber Pigtail
gearList.name: Fiber_Pigtail

gearList.description: Secures the interface (fusion or mechanical) between the fiber drop and pigtail.
gearList.title: Fiber Splice
gearList.name: Fiber_Splice

gearList.description: Houses and secures the fusion splices between the feeder and the fiberoptic patch cords.
gearList.title: Fiber Splice Tray
gearList.name: Fiber_Splice_Tray

gearList.html: Available in orange to wrap around fiberoptic cables in 4" and 8" lengths. May be labelled or plain.
gearList.description: Identifies the fiberoptic cable among other similar-looking cables
gearList.title: Fiber Wraparound Marker
gearList.name: Fiber_Wraparound_Marker

gearList.html:
Learn more about fiberoptic communications...
  • Clearfield Cabinets
gearList.description: Houses fiber termination equipment in a secure cabinet.
gearList.title: Fiberoptic Cabinet
gearList.name: Fiberoptic_Cabinet

gearList.html:
Learn more about fiberoptics...
  • SCTE/ISBE FTTx 99 Explainer
  • Discover how we use fiber in the OSP
  • RF over Glass
  • Inspecting and cleaning fiber
  • Commscope Fiber Catalog
  • SCUPC vs. SCAPC Connectors
  • How do we splice fiberoptic cable?
gearList.description: Carries video, voice, and data traffic as encoded pulses of infrared laser light between the headend, hubs, nodes, optical line terminals (OLT), and other fiberoptic equipment.
gearList.title: Fiberoptic Cable
gearList.name: Fiberoptic_Cable

gearList.html: Fuses are available in different form factors depending on the vendor and model of the amplifier.
gearList.description: Protects amplifiers from damage due to an electrical fault.
gearList.title: Fuse
gearList.name: Fuse

gearList.html:
Learn more...
  • What is the XBox?
  • What is the PlayStation?
gearList.description: Delivers interactive gaming to the customer.
gearList.title: Game Console
gearList.name: Game_Console

gearList.html:
Learn more...
  • DOCSIS 3.1 Overview 99 Primer
  • What is the topology of hardline cable?
  • Try it! Identify Hardline Topologies
  • What are the components of a hardline cable?
  • Commscope Hardline Cable
gearList.description: Provides the backbone of the coaxial distribution system to transport (RF) signals and AC voltage among nodes, amplifiers, taps, and standby power supplies.
gearList.title: Hardline Cable
gearList.name: Hardline_Cable

gearList.html: Available in 2- and 3-piece connectors; installed and tightened down with a seizure screw inside the housing
gearList.description: Provides a secure, watertight connection between a hardline cable and nodes, amplifiers, and taps.
gearList.title: Hardline Connector
gearList.name: Hardline_Connector

gearList.html: The hardline splitter acts as both a splitter for the downstream RF carriers and combiner for the upstream RF carriers.
gearList.description: Splits the signal on the hardline cable.
gearList.title: Hardline Splitter
gearList.name: Hardline_Splitter

gearList.html: • SCTE/ISBE: Headend Facilities
gearList.description: Connects the hubs and nodes over fiberoptic cable to video, voice, and data services. The headend facility houses electronic equipment to receive, process, and transmit data, and may use local over-the-air (OTA) antennas and television receive-only (TVRO) satellite dishes.
gearList.title: Headend
gearList.name: Headend

gearList.html: Hubs are connected to a regional headend with fiberoptic cable and may include Edge QAMs, combiners, laser transmitters and receivers, and other CATV equipment.
gearList.description: Houses CATV gear to provide video, voice and data services closer to the subscribers.
gearList.title: Hub
gearList.name: Hub

gearList.html: Used in pairs, in-span fiber slack storage, such as the Multilink Sno-Shoe, stores additional fiberoptic cable (slack), allowing the splice case to be moved into a trailer.
gearList.description: Stores fiberoptic cable hanging from the strand.
gearList.title: In-Span Fiber Slack Storage
gearList.name: In-Span_Fiber_Slack_Storage

gearList.html: Inside wire should be RG6 but older installations may be RG59, which has a higher attenuation across the spectrum.
gearList.description: Carries RF signals between the RF Demarc to the cable outlets inside the customer premises.
gearList.title: Inside Wire
gearList.name: Inside_Wire

gearList.html:
Learn more..
  • How does the IRT work?
gearList.description: The Integrated Receiver Transcoder (IRT) converts the incoming signal from the TVRO antenna into a standard format, such as an MPEG2 transport stream, and outputs over ASI or GigE.
gearList.title: Integrated Receiver Transcoder
gearList.name: Integrated_Receiver_Transcoder

gearList.html: IP cameras (hard-wired and WiFi) are part of the growing trend in home automation.
gearList.description: Operates over the Internet to monitor and record video and audio.
gearList.title: IP Security Camera
gearList.name: IP_Security_Camera

gearList.html:
Learn more..
  • Are there different types of laser receivers?
  • How do laser receivers work?
gearList.description: Converts the optical pulses on the returns into RF signals.
gearList.title: Laser Receiver
gearList.name: Laser_Receiver

gearList.html:
Learn more..
  • Are there different types of laser transmitters?
  • How do laser transmitters work?
gearList.description: Converts the modulated RF carrier to optical pulses which are transmitted down the fiberoptic cable.
gearList.title: Laser Transmitter
gearList.name: Laser_Transmitter

gearList.html: Galvanized steel clamps are used to secure the lashing wire wrapped around the cables to the strand.
gearList.description: Secures lashing wire to strand
gearList.title: Lashing Clamp
gearList.name: Lashing_Clamp

gearList.description: Secures cable to strand
gearList.title: Lashing Wire
gearList.name: Lashing_Wire

gearList.html: Straps are used with spacers and are available in different lengths and widths to support individual cables or bundles.
gearList.description: Straps hardline cable, drop cable, and fiberoptic cable to the strand.
gearList.title: Lashing Support Strap
gearList.name: Lashing_Support_Strap

gearList.html:
Learn more...
  • What is MOCA?
  • How do I install a MOCA local area network?
  • What is Ethernet?
  • What is an Ethernet port?
  • Are all Ethernet cables the same?
gearList.description: Uses MOCA frequencies to encode and decode Ethernet frames using existing coax inside wire. The device is designed to extend a wired Ethernet port from the cable modem or gateway to a remote part of the customer's facility.
gearList.title: MOCA Ethernet Extender
gearList.name: MOCA_Ethernet_Extender

gearList.html:
Learn more...
  • What is MOCA?
  • What's the best way to install a MOCA local area network?
  • What's WiFi?
  • What's a WiFi extender?
gearList.description: Uses MOCA frequencies to encode and decode Ethernet frames using existing coax inside wire. The device is designed to extend the WiFi service from the cable modem, router, or gateway device to remote areas of the customer's location.
gearList.title: MOCA WiFi Extender
gearList.name: MOCA_WiFi_Extender

gearList.html:
Learn more...
  • What is Network-attached Storage (NAS)?
  • Who makes NAS devices?
  • What is RAID?
gearList.description: Provides network-available storage and retrieval of large amounts of data such as videos, movies, pictures, and document files.
gearList.title: Network Attached Storage
gearList.name: Network_Attached_Storage

gearList.html:
Also known as an optical node, this device is the key component in an HFC network; a failure here will affect hundreds of customers. Noise from the customers funnel into the node and may affect its performance. Learn more...
  • Try it! Identify the role of the node.
  • Try it! Identify optical components
  • Try it! How does a node work?
  • Pace/Aurora Advanced Services Node
gearList.description: The node is the interface between the fiberoptic cable and the hardline cable in a HFC network. The node is an active device, meaning that it requires power from a power supply, inserted into the node by the power inserter.
gearList.title: Node
gearList.name: Node

gearList.html: The Over-the-Air (OTA) Antenna is mounted on a tower at the headend.
gearList.description: Receives digital TV signals from local stations.
gearList.title: Over-the-Air (OTA) Antenna
gearList.name: Over-the-Air_OTA_Antenna

gearList.html: The RFoG ONU acts as a mini node, converting optical signals in the downstream for voice, video, and data into RF, to be carried over the customers inside wire to the cable modem, gateway, or set top box. In the upstream, the ONU converts RF into optical signals to be carried back to the hub or headend over the fiberoptic cable.
gearList.description: Converts light to RF and vice versa. Used in FTTH Demarc enclosures with RF over Glass (RFoG) topologies.
gearList.title: Optical Network Unit ONU
gearList.name: Optical_Network_Unit_ONU

gearList.html: Pads are available in a number of dB values
gearList.description: Attenuates the signal as it passes through the amplifier module.
gearList.title: Pad
gearList.name: Pad

gearList.description: Combines the channel output signals of the various video and audio devices.
gearList.title: Passive Combiner
gearList.name: Passive_Combiner

gearList.html: Pedestals are typically two pieces, a stationary base and a removable cover. There are many types of underground-plant access points: Pedestals, hand-holds, and cabinets are just a few.
gearList.description: Protects the active and passive devices connected to the underground plant via a tap.
gearList.title: Pedestal
gearList.name: Pedestal

gearList.html: Passively combines RF with up to 90VAC to power active electronics on the hardline cable.
gearList.description: Inserts AC power from the power supply onto the hardline cable.
gearList.title: Power Inserter
gearList.name: Power_Inserter

gearList.html:
• The Alpha XM3-HP CableUPS
  • AlphaNet DM3 Series Transponder Installation Certification Course
  • AlphaNet DM3 Series Transponder Installation Quick Start Guide
  • Ride Along: Responding to a Power Supply Alarm
  • Safety Tip: Exploding Batteries
  • Activity: Battery Safety
  • Activity: Electrical Safety Tips for Power Supplies
  • Ride Along: Power Supply Components
  • Inside the Power Supply Cabinet
  • Activity: Identify Power Supply Cabinet Elements
  • Reviewing the Alpha XM2
  • The XM2 Functional Block Diagram
  • Transponder Functions
  • Activity: Transponder Functions
  • Activity: Power Supply Alarms
gearList.description: Regulates utility power to provide clean AC power over hardline cable to active electronics in the OSP, such as nodes, amplifiers, and Wireless Hubs.
gearList.title: Power Supply
gearList.name: Power_Supply

gearList.description: Protects the power supply, batteries, and associated electronics.
gearList.title: Power Supply Cabinet
gearList.name: Power_Supply_Cabinet

gearList.description: Encodes analog and digital baseband signals and outputs an MPEG2 transport stream over GigE.
gearList.title: QAM Add/Drop Inserter
gearList.name: QAM_Add_Drop_Inserter

gearList.html: QAM modulators are rack mounted. Each one controls where on the RF spectrum the QAM carrier is placed.
gearList.description: Uses the MPEG-2 digital transport stream, input using GigE, to modulate an RF carrier.
gearList.title: QAM Modulator
gearList.name: QAM_Modulator

gearList.html:
Learn more....
  • What are MPEG2, MPEG4, and the other digital video standards?
  • What are transport streams?
  • Some Analog to Digital Encoders
  • Some Digital Encoders
gearList.description: Converts multiple formats of digital and analog video into an MPEG2 transport stream over a GigE interface.
gearList.title: Receiver Encoder
gearList.name: Receiver_Encoder

gearList.html:
Learn more...
  • What is a firewall?
  • What is a server?
  • What is a web server?
  • How does cable telephony work?
  • What is an electronic program guide?
  • Why are OSS/BSS important?
  • All about ACTI TVRO Antennas.
  • All about Althos Ad Insertion.
  • All about VOD from Edgeware.
gearList.description: Monitors and controls the status of signals, devices, and facilities.
gearList.title: Regional Operations Center
gearList.name: Regional_Operations_Center

gearList.html: Power modules (power packs) are replaceable and vary in form factor depending on vendor and amplifier model.
gearList.description: Converts AC to regulated DC in order to power the electronics.
gearList.title: Regulated Power Module
gearList.name: Regulated_Power_Module

gearList.html:
Learn more...
  • Are there different types of combiners?
  • What frequencies are used?
gearList.description: Combines the RF feeds from the QAM modulators, CMTS, and other RF equipment.
gearList.title: RF Combiner
gearList.name: RF_Combiner

gearList.html:
Learn more...
  • Why do we bond to ground?
  • What options do we have for bonding to ground??
  • When do we use a MOCA filter?
gearList.description: Houses the physical interface between the drop and the customer's inside wire.
gearList.title: RF Demarc
gearList.name: RF_Demarc

gearList.html: The RFoG ONU acts as a mini-node, converting optical signals in the downstream for voice, video, and data into RF, to be carried over the customers inside wire to the cable modem, gateway, or set top box. In the upstream, the ONU converts RF into optical signals to be carried back to the hub or headend over the fiberoptic cable.
gearList.description: Serves as a mini-node in a FTTH demarc supporting RF over Glass (RFoG).
gearList.title: RFoG Optical Network Unit (ONU)
gearList.name: RFoG_Optical_Network_Unit_ONU_

gearList.html:
Learn more...
  • What is home automation?
  • What is the Internet of Things (IoT)?
  • What is UHD?
  • What is Xfinity Home?
  • What is IntelligentHome?
  • What is Suddenlink Security?
gearList.description: Configures and controls security and home automation devices installed by the cable operator.
gearList.title: Security Panel
gearList.name: Security_Panel

gearList.html:
Learn more...
  • What is a server?
  • What is a web server?
  • What is UHD?
  • What is Xfinity Home?
  • What is IntelligentHome?
  • What is Suddenlink Security?
gearList.description: Provides storage and retrieval of web pages, configuration files, and logs of system and device status.
gearList.title: Server
gearList.name: Server

gearList.html: A heat gun or torch is used to shrink the tubing
gearList.description: Protects hardline connectors from the elements.
gearList.title: Shrink Tube
gearList.name: Shrink_Tube

gearList.html:
Used aerially or in a pedestal. The splice case is available in a variety of sizes and configurations. Designed with fiberoptic cable slack, stored using the sno shoes, the case can be easily removed and placed in a splicing truck, out of the weather.
  • Commscope Splice Cases
gearList.description: Secures the fiber splices in a protective case.
gearList.title: Splice Case
gearList.name: Splice_Case

gearList.html:
Passively splits the downstream and combines the upstream RF signals at the customer location.
  • What are the losses through a splitter?
gearList.description: Splits and combines the RF signals to support multiple CPE devices.
gearList.title: Splitter
gearList.name: Splitter

gearList.html: Strand is stranded galvanized steel cable, available in 1/4", 5/16", and 3/8" diameters. Strand is also called messenger and is connected to utility poles. Strand can support thousands of pounds.
gearList.description: Attaches to utility poles to support aerial cable and electronics in the OSP.
gearList.title: Strand
gearList.name: Strand

gearList.html: Galvanized steel clamps are used on poles to secure the strand in place and are available in straight-through (shown) or corner pole (right angle).
gearList.description: Secures strand to pole or support
gearList.title: Strand Suspension Clamp
gearList.name: Strand_Suspension_Clamp

gearList.html: The RF signal received by the antenna is typically a modulated MPEG4 stream which has to be converted to an MPEG2 transport stream. The RF signal from the antenna is routed to a integrated receiver transcoder (IRT) for this process.
gearList.description: The TV Receive-only (TVRO) antenna receives programming from national networks at the headend.
gearList.title: TV Receive Only Dish
gearList.name: TV_Receive_Only_Dish

gearList.html: Taps are available in 2, 4, and 8 ports and in varying dB levels of attenuation.
gearList.description: Splits the downstream RF spectrum to multiple drop cables and combines the upstreams from the drops.
gearList.title: Tap
gearList.name: Tap

gearList.html: The IRD decodes the digital data from the satellite and rebuilds it into a signal compatible with other headend/hub processing equipment.
gearList.description: Converts the Integrated Receiver Decoder (IRD) output signal to a format that can be connected to the hub router and switch.
gearList.title: Transcoder
gearList.name: Transcoder

gearList.description: Demodulates the ASI and QAM transport streams so they can be checked for quality.
gearList.title: Transport Stream (TS) Analyzer
gearList.name: Transport_Stream_TS_Analyzer

gearList.html:
Learn more...
  • What is TV resolution?
  • What is aspect ratio?
  • What is UHD?
  • What is HDMI 2.0?
  • What is RoKu?
  • What is ChromeCast?
  • How do I program a remote?
gearList.description: A TV displays and outputs the program information (video, audio, guide, metadata)
gearList.title: TV
gearList.name: TV

gearList.html: WiFi thermostats are part of the growing trend in home automation.
gearList.description: Operates on the Internet of Things (IoT). May be configured, operated, and monitored over the internet.
gearList.title: WiFi Thermostat
gearList.name: WiFi_Thermostat

gearList.html: Also known as a Hotspot, the WiFi hub broadcasts multiple network names for use by mobile and fixed devices nearby. These hubs enable Internet access similar to a wireless router in the home.
gearList.description: Provides access to the Internet and to the carrier's private network using WiFi.
gearList.title: Wireless Hub
gearList.name: Wireless_Hub

gearList.description: Tightens and loosens connectors and splices.
gearList.title: Adjustable Wrenches
gearList.name: Adjustable_Wrenches

gearList.description: Adjusts internal amp components - made of anti-static material.
gearList.title: Anti-Static Trim and Alignment Tools
gearList.name: Anti-Static_Trim_and_Alignment_Tools

gearList.description: Removes waste dielectric from the center conductor after coring.
gearList.title: Cleaner/Scraper
gearList.name: Cleaner_Scraper

gearList.description: Shrinks the tubing around connectors to make a weather-resistant seal.
gearList.title: Cordless Heat Gun
gearList.name: Cordless_Heat_Gun

gearList.description: Ensures proper torque on case bolts in order to make sure the case gasket is not deformed as the bolts are tightened.
gearList.title: Foot-Pound Torque Wrench
gearList.name: Foot-Pound_Torque_Wrench

gearList.description: Removes the dielectric foam inside the hardline cable to prep it for a connector.
gearList.title: Hardline Coring Tool
gearList.name: Hardline_Coring_Tool

gearList.description: Trims the hardline cable.
gearList.title: Hardline Cutter
gearList.name: Hardline_Cutter

gearList.description: Loosens and tightens hex screws
gearList.title: Hex Key Set
gearList.name: Hex_Key_Set

gearList.description: Tightens connectors to specified torque to avoid deforming gaskets.
gearList.title: Inch-Pound Torque Wrench
gearList.name: Inch-Pound_Torque_Wrench

gearList.description: Grabs, holds,  tightens, and loosens the fittings found in the OSP.
gearList.title: Pliers Set
gearList.name: Pliers_Set

gearList.description: Tightens and loosens seizure screws and used for general purposes where needed.
gearList.title: Screwdriver Set
gearList.name: Screwdriver_Set

gearList.description: Loosens and tightens bolts on multiple devices and support gear in the OSP.
gearList.title: Socket and Box Wrench Kit
gearList.name: Socket_and_Box_Wrench_Kit

infowins.html: The 180 Degree Adapter helps to connect the hardline to devices when working in tight spaces.
infowins.description: Provides a right-angle connector for hardline cable.
infowins.title: 180 Degree Adapter
infowins.name: _180_Degree_Adapter

infowins.html: Available in different lengths.
infowins.description: Connects hardline cable to devices when working in tight spaces.
infowins.title: 180 Degree Socket Adapter
infowins.name: _180_Degree_Socket_Adapter

infowins.description: Combines the channel output signals of the video and audio devices and adds program-specific information.
infowins.title: Active Combiner
infowins.name: Active_Combiner

infowins.description: Secures the drop to the span in a way that allows for expansion.
infowins.title: Aerial Drop Clamp
infowins.name: Aerial_Drop_Clamp

infowins.html:
The goal of amplifiers is to maintain unity gain across the coaxial plant. Amplifiers are found on the express cable (trunk); bridge the RF onto multiple legs (bridger and mini-bridger), and extend the signal to end-of-line (EOL) customers (line extenders). Learn more...
  • How does an amp work?
  • Try it! Relate design to operation.
  • Trunk and Bridger Amps from DFC
  • Line Extenders from DFC
infowins.description: Rebuilds the original RF signal from the node, correcting RF signal degradation caused by transport through the hardline cable. Combines and amplifies carriers on the return and transmits them to the node.
infowins.title: Amplifier
infowins.name: Amplifier

infowins.html: The amplifier module is easily replaced in the event of damage or failure
infowins.description: Houses the active electronics inside the amplifier case.
infowins.title: Amplifier Module
infowins.name: Amplifier_Module

infowins.html: The barrel connector is a splice, built with a brass insert to connect the center conductors together and a dielectric.
infowins.description: Provides the physical interface for the short cable connecting to the DVR, MOCA Node, DTA, or Cable Modem.
infowins.title: Barrel Connector
infowins.name: Barrel_Connector

infowins.html: Amplifies the downstream and allows the upstream to pass. The amplifier is installed inside and powered using an AC/DC power block. Power runs over the coax inside wire.
infowins.description: Amplifies the downstream RF energy to meet specified signal levels in order to operate the CPE.
infowins.title: Bi-Directional Amplifier
infowins.name: Bi-Directional_Amplifier

infowins.html: Bonding blocks are sometimes still called "ground blocks." The block acts as a test point and protects the OSP and the customer's equipment.
infowins.description: Provides the interface between the drop and the customer's inside wire and bonds to the building grounding system to protect against shock and damage from electrical surges.
infowins.title: Bonding Block
infowins.name: Bonding_Block

infowins.html: The bonding clamp is designed to minimize electrolytic corrosion caused by bonding copper to steel. It is essential for electrical safety.
infowins.description: Clamps the building wire to the strand.
infowins.title: Bonding Clamp
infowins.name: Bonding_Clamp

infowins.html: Bonding to ground is a critical element of all subscriber installations.
infowins.description: Carries excess voltage to the building's ground system. Bonding wire is designed to carry voltage from surges like lightning.
infowins.title: Bonding Wire
infowins.name: Bonding_Wire

infowins.html: Building wire is also called riser bond and is available in large gauge 4AWG and 8AWG. Building wire is clamped to the strand and run through the riser to a ground rod at the base of the pole.
infowins.description: Bonds the strand to a ground rod to protect the devices and technicians from electrical shock.
infowins.title: Building Wire
infowins.name: Building_Wire

infowins.html:
Learn more about cable modems and gateways (includes telephone jacks)
  • Arris Cable Modem and Gateway Quick-Start guides
  • What is the IoT?
  • How do Internet cameras work?
  • What is WiFi?
  • What are WiFi boosters, repeaters, and extenders?
  • What's new in WiFi?
  • How can I troubleshoot my Internet connection?
  • How can I change the settings on the cable modem?
infowins.description: Provides high-speed Internet services using DOCSIS.
infowins.title: Cable Modem
infowins.name: Cable_Modem

infowins.html: Also called a TV Wall Plate, the faceplate includes a barrel connector, threaded at both ends.
infowins.description: Demarcs the inside wire at the wall.
infowins.title: CATV Wall Outlet
infowins.name: CATV_Wall_Outlet

infowins.html:
Learn more about CCAP/CMTS...
  • Discover the role of the headend and hub
  • SCTE's IP Engineering Professional course
  • CCAP and the headend
infowins.description: The Converged Cable Access Platform (CCAP)/Cable Modem Termination System (CMTS) control the modulation and demodulation of digital RF carriers.
infowins.title: CCAP/CMTS
infowins.name: CCAP_CMTS

infowins.html: The device is commonly called a "Cherry Picker" because it picks and organizes the program streams into the channel lineup.
infowins.description: Assembles and interleaves the MPEG2 transport streams into each of the digital carriers.
infowins.title: Cherry Picker/MUX
infowins.name: Cherry_Picker_MUX

infowins.html: Compression connectors used outside often have rubber grommets to provide a watertight seal. The compression fitting is designed to secure the cable's sheath without deforming the dielectric foam insulation.
infowins.description: Connects drop cable and inside wire to bonding blocks, splitters, and equipment.
infowins.title: Compression F-Connector
infowins.name: Compression_F-Connector

infowins.html: Connects to an AC/DC power block.
infowins.description: Injects DC to power a bi-directional amplifier.
infowins.title: DC Power Inserter
infowins.name: DC_Power_Inserter

infowins.html: The demodulator's baseband output can be SD or HD. The output signal is inserted into the multiplexer through the router.
infowins.description: Converts video and audio RF signals to baseband.
infowins.title: Demodulator
infowins.name: Demodulator

infowins.html: With a coaxial input, the DTA processes the digital data to output HDMI (HD models), Composite, or IF Baseband (Channel 3/4).
infowins.description: The Digital Terminal Adapter (DTA) decodes the digital programming so it can be displayed on a TV.
infowins.title: Digital Terminal Adapter
infowins.name: Digital_Terminal_Adapter

infowins.html: A DVR, also called a Digital Video Recorder, receives a channel guide which is loaded on the box. It also transmits status messages to a set top box monitoring server.
infowins.description: The Digital Video Recorder (DVR)Decodes the digital audio and video for display on a TV. Also records and stores the programming for playback at a later time.
infowins.title: Digital Video Recorder
infowins.name: Digital_Video_Recorder

infowins.html: Also called a network interface unit (NIU), network interface device (NID), and house box, the enclosure protects the bonding block, connectors, and /or splitters from the elements.
infowins.description: Houses the physical interface between the fiber drop and the customer's inside wire.
infowins.title: Fiber Demarcation Enclosure
infowins.name: Fiber_Demarcation_Enclosure

infowins.html:
Learn about drop cables...
  • Fiberoptic drop cables from FS
  • Coaxial drop cable from Commscope
infowins.description: Transports the signals for voice, video, and data between the tap and the demarc. In RF demarcs the drop cable is coaxial (RG6 or RG11) and runs from the tap to the demarc. In FTTH demarcs, the drop cable is low count fiber and a short RG6 drop is used inside the demarc between the ONU and the inside wire. Drop cables are identified by drop tags.
infowins.title: Drop Cable
infowins.name: Drop_Cable

infowins.html: Drop tags come in different colors to identify the type of drop and the customer it serves.
infowins.description: Identifies the assigned subscriber and service status [active/disconnected/filtered] for the tagged drop cable.
infowins.title: Drop Tag
infowins.name: Drop_Tag

infowins.html: Also referred to as a mid-span clamp, the E Span Clamp is one of a number of clamps used to secure the drop cable to the strand and position it away from driveways and property lines.
infowins.description: Secures the drop along the span.
infowins.title: E Span Clamp
infowins.name: E_Span_Clamp

infowins.html: The EAS antenna is mounted outdoors.
infowins.description: Receives the EAS public safety broadcasts that activate the EAS system in the headend.
infowins.title: Emergency Alert System (EAS) Antenna
infowins.name: Emergency_Alert_System_EAS_Antenna

infowins.html: The EAS antenna is mounted outdoors.
infowins.description: Activates upon receipt of an EAS broadcast and interrupts all transport streams and inserts the audio and text message.
infowins.title: Emergency Alert System (EAS) Controller
infowins.name: Emergency_Alert_System_EAS_Controller

infowins.html: Equalizer modules vary in form factor depending on the vendor and model of the amplifier.
infowins.description: Adjusts the gain in the lower, middle, and upper frequency bands in amplifiers.
infowins.title: Equalizer
infowins.name: Equalizer

infowins.html:
The fiber-to-the-home (FTTH) demarc is a weather-resistant enclosure that houses the components used to connect the OSP to the customers inside wire. The drop is fiberoptic cable. In an RFoG Demarc, a mini-node optical network unit (ONU) converts light to RF (downstream) and RF to light (upstream).
  • Check out this RFoG enclosure from Alpha
  • RFoG explained
infowins.description: Houses the components used to interface the fiber drop to the customer's inside wire.
infowins.title: FTTH Demarc
infowins.name: FTTH_Demarc

infowins.html:
Find out more about Mux/Demux units...
  • Commscope Dual LGX Module Wavelength Division Multiplexer
  • Commscope FTTX Brightpath Solutions
infowins.description: Combines (Mux) multiple optical signals onto a single fiber. Breaks out (Demux) multiple optical signals from a single fiber.
infowins.title: Fiber Mux/Demux
infowins.name: Fiber_Mux_Demux

infowins.description: Cross connects optical devices such as ONUs, ONTs, and nodes to the correct fiber or wavelength associated with that device.
infowins.title: Fiber Patch Panel
infowins.name: Fiber_Patch_Panel

infowins.html:
Unterminated fiber needs a pigtail spliced onto it. Learn more...
  • Types of connectors - APC vs. UPC
  • A great view of an SC-APC pigtail from European supplier Dipol
infowins.description: Provides a connector to insert into the optical network unit (ONU). The pigtail is spliced onto the fiberoptic drop cable.
infowins.title: Fiber Pigtail
infowins.name: Fiber_Pigtail

infowins.description: Secures the interface (fusion or mechanical) between the fiber drop and pigtail.
infowins.title: Fiber Splice
infowins.name: Fiber_Splice

infowins.description: Houses and secures the fusion splices between the feeder and the fiberoptic patch cords.
infowins.title: Fiber Splice Tray
infowins.name: Fiber_Splice_Tray

infowins.html: Available in orange to wrap around fiberoptic cables in 4" and 8" lengths. May be labelled or plain.
infowins.description: Identifies the fiberoptic cable among other similar-looking cables
infowins.title: Fiber Wraparound Marker
infowins.name: Fiber_Wraparound_Marker

infowins.html:
Learn more about fiberoptic communications...
  • Clearfield Cabinets
infowins.description: Houses fiber termination equipment in a secure cabinet.
infowins.title: Fiberoptic Cabinet
infowins.name: Fiberoptic_Cabinet

infowins.html:
Learn more about fiberoptics...
  • SCTE/ISBE FTTx 99 Explainer
  • Discover how we use fiber in the OSP
  • RF over Glass
  • Inspecting and cleaning fiber
  • Commscope Fiber Catalog
  • SCUPC vs. SCAPC Connectors
  • How do we splice fiberoptic cable?
infowins.description: Carries video, voice, and data traffic as encoded pulses of infrared laser light between the headend, hubs, nodes, optical line terminals (OLT), and other fiberoptic equipment.
infowins.title: Fiberoptic Cable
infowins.name: Fiberoptic_Cable

infowins.html: Fuses are available in different form factors depending on the vendor and model of the amplifier.
infowins.description: Protects amplifiers from damage due to an electrical fault.
infowins.title: Fuse
infowins.name: Fuse

infowins.html:
Learn more...
  • What is the XBox?
  • What is the PlayStation?
infowins.description: Delivers interactive gaming to the customer.
infowins.title: Game Console
infowins.name: Game_Console

infowins.html:
Learn more...
  • DOCSIS 3.1 Overview 99 Primer
  • What is the topology of hardline cable?
  • Try it! Identify Hardline Topologies
  • What are the components of a hardline cable?
  • Commscope Hardline Cable
infowins.description: Provides the backbone of the coaxial distribution system to transport (RF) signals and AC voltage among nodes, amplifiers, taps, and standby power supplies.
infowins.title: Hardline Cable
infowins.name: Hardline_Cable

infowins.html: Available in 2- and 3-piece connectors; installed and tightened down with a seizure screw inside the housing
infowins.description: Provides a secure, watertight connection between a hardline cable and nodes, amplifiers, and taps.
infowins.title: Hardline Connector
infowins.name: Hardline_Connector

infowins.html: The hardline splitter acts as both a splitter for the downstream RF carriers and combiner for the upstream RF carriers.
infowins.description: Splits the signal on the hardline cable.
infowins.title: Hardline Splitter
infowins.name: Hardline_Splitter

infowins.html: • SCTE/ISBE: Headend Facilities
infowins.description: Connects the hubs and nodes over fiberoptic cable to video, voice, and data services. The headend facility houses electronic equipment to receive, process, and transmit data, and may use local over-the-air (OTA) antennas and television receive-only (TVRO) satellite dishes.
infowins.title: Headend
infowins.name: Headend

infowins.html: Hubs are connected to a regional headend with fiberoptic cable and may include Edge QAMs, combiners, laser transmitters and receivers, and other CATV equipment.
infowins.description: Houses CATV gear to provide video, voice and data services closer to the subscribers.
infowins.title: Hub
infowins.name: Hub

infowins.html: Used in pairs, in-span fiber slack storage, such as the Multilink Sno-Shoe, stores additional fiberoptic cable (slack), allowing the splice case to be moved into a trailer.
infowins.description: Stores fiberoptic cable hanging from the strand.
infowins.title: In-Span Fiber Slack Storage
infowins.name: In-Span_Fiber_Slack_Storage

infowins.html: Inside wire should be RG6 but older installations may be RG59, which has a higher attenuation across the spectrum.
infowins.description: Carries RF signals between the RF Demarc to the cable outlets inside the customer premises.
infowins.title: Inside Wire
infowins.name: Inside_Wire

infowins.html:
Learn more..
  • How does the IRT work?
infowins.description: The Integrated Receiver Transcoder (IRT) converts the incoming signal from the TVRO antenna into a standard format, such as an MPEG2 transport stream, and outputs over ASI or GigE.
infowins.title: Integrated Receiver Transcoder
infowins.name: Integrated_Receiver_Transcoder

infowins.html: IP cameras (hard-wired and WiFi) are part of the growing trend in home automation.
infowins.description: Operates over the Internet to monitor and record video and audio.
infowins.title: IP Security Camera
infowins.name: IP_Security_Camera

infowins.html:
Learn more..
  • Are there different types of laser receivers?
  • How do laser receivers work?
infowins.description: Converts the optical pulses on the returns into RF signals.
infowins.title: Laser Receiver
infowins.name: Laser_Receiver

infowins.html:
Learn more..
  • Are there different types of laser transmitters?
  • How do laser transmitters work?
infowins.description: Converts the modulated RF carrier to optical pulses which are transmitted down the fiberoptic cable.
infowins.title: Laser Transmitter
infowins.name: Laser_Transmitter

infowins.html: Galvanized steel clamps are used to secure the lashing wire wrapped around the cables to the strand.
infowins.description: Secures lashing wire to strand
infowins.title: Lashing Clamp
infowins.name: Lashing_Clamp

infowins.description: Secures cable to strand
infowins.title: Lashing Wire
infowins.name: Lashing_Wire

infowins.html: Straps are used with spacers and are available in different lengths and widths to support individual cables or bundles.
infowins.description: Straps hardline cable, drop cable, and fiberoptic cable to the strand.
infowins.title: Lashing Support Strap
infowins.name: Lashing_Support_Strap

infowins.html:
Learn more...
  • What is MOCA?
  • How do I install a MOCA local area network?
  • What is Ethernet?
  • What is an Ethernet port?
  • Are all Ethernet cables the same?
infowins.description: Uses MOCA frequencies to encode and decode Ethernet frames using existing coax inside wire. The device is designed to extend a wired Ethernet port from the cable modem or gateway to a remote part of the customer's facility.
infowins.title: MOCA Ethernet Extender
infowins.name: MOCA_Ethernet_Extender

infowins.html:
Learn more...
  • What is MOCA?
  • What's the best way to install a MOCA local area network?
  • What's WiFi?
  • What's a WiFi extender?
infowins.description: Uses MOCA frequencies to encode and decode Ethernet frames using existing coax inside wire. The device is designed to extend the WiFi service from the cable modem, router, or gateway device to remote areas of the customer's location.
infowins.title: MOCA WiFi Extender
infowins.name: MOCA_WiFi_Extender

infowins.html:
Learn more...
  • What is Network-attached Storage (NAS)?
  • Who makes NAS devices?
  • What is RAID?
infowins.description: Provides network-available storage and retrieval of large amounts of data such as videos, movies, pictures, and document files.
infowins.title: Network Attached Storage
infowins.name: Network_Attached_Storage

infowins.html:
Also known as an optical node, this device is the key component in an HFC network; a failure here will affect hundreds of customers. Noise from the customers funnel into the node and may affect its performance. Learn more...
  • Try it! Identify the role of the node.
  • Try it! Identify optical components
  • Try it! How does a node work?
  • Pace/Aurora Advanced Services Node
infowins.description: The node is the interface between the fiberoptic cable and the hardline cable in a HFC network. The node is an active device, meaning that it requires power from a power supply, inserted into the node by the power inserter.
infowins.title: Node
infowins.name: Node

infowins.html: The Over-the-Air (OTA) Antenna is mounted on a tower at the headend.
infowins.description: Receives digital TV signals from local stations.
infowins.title: Over-the-Air (OTA) Antenna
infowins.name: Over-the-Air_OTA_Antenna

infowins.html: The RFoG ONU acts as a mini node, converting optical signals in the downstream for voice, video, and data into RF, to be carried over the customers inside wire to the cable modem, gateway, or set top box. In the upstream, the ONU converts RF into optical signals to be carried back to the hub or headend over the fiberoptic cable.
infowins.description: Converts light to RF and vice versa. Used in FTTH Demarc enclosures with RF over Glass (RFoG) topologies.
infowins.title: Optical Network Unit ONU
infowins.name: Optical_Network_Unit_ONU

infowins.html: Pads are available in a number of dB values
infowins.description: Attenuates the signal as it passes through the amplifier module.
infowins.title: Pad
infowins.name: Pad

infowins.description: Combines the channel output signals of the various video and audio devices.
infowins.title: Passive Combiner
infowins.name: Passive_Combiner

infowins.html: Pedestals are typically two pieces, a stationary base and a removable cover. There are many types of underground-plant access points: Pedestals, hand-holds, and cabinets are just a few.
infowins.description: Protects the active and passive devices connected to the underground plant via a tap.
infowins.title: Pedestal
infowins.name: Pedestal

infowins.html: Passively combines RF with up to 90VAC to power active electronics on the hardline cable.
infowins.description: Inserts AC power from the power supply onto the hardline cable.
infowins.title: Power Inserter
infowins.name: Power_Inserter

infowins.html:
• The Alpha XM3-HP CableUPS
  • AlphaNet DM3 Series Transponder Installation Certification Course
  • AlphaNet DM3 Series Transponder Installation Quick Start Guide
  • Ride Along: Responding to a Power Supply Alarm
  • Safety Tip: Exploding Batteries
  • Activity: Battery Safety
  • Activity: Electrical Safety Tips for Power Supplies
  • Ride Along: Power Supply Components
  • Inside the Power Supply Cabinet
  • Activity: Identify Power Supply Cabinet Elements
  • Reviewing the Alpha XM2
  • The XM2 Functional Block Diagram
  • Transponder Functions
  • Activity: Transponder Functions
  • Activity: Power Supply Alarms
infowins.description: Regulates utility power to provide clean AC power over hardline cable to active electronics in the OSP, such as nodes, amplifiers, and Wireless Hubs.
infowins.title: Power Supply
infowins.name: Power_Supply

infowins.description: Protects the power supply, batteries, and associated electronics.
infowins.title: Power Supply Cabinet
infowins.name: Power_Supply_Cabinet

infowins.description: Encodes analog and digital baseband signals and outputs an MPEG2 transport stream over GigE.
infowins.title: QAM Add/Drop Inserter
infowins.name: QAM_Add_Drop_Inserter

infowins.html: QAM modulators are rack mounted. Each one controls where on the RF spectrum the QAM carrier is placed.
infowins.description: Uses the MPEG-2 digital transport stream, input using GigE, to modulate an RF carrier.
infowins.title: QAM Modulator
infowins.name: QAM_Modulator

infowins.html:
Learn more....
  • What are MPEG2, MPEG4, and the other digital video standards?
  • What are transport streams?
  • Some Analog to Digital Encoders
  • Some Digital Encoders
infowins.description: Converts multiple formats of digital and analog video into an MPEG2 transport stream over a GigE interface.
infowins.title: Receiver Encoder
infowins.name: Receiver_Encoder

infowins.html:
Learn more...
  • What is a firewall?
  • What is a server?
  • What is a web server?
  • How does cable telephony work?
  • What is an electronic program guide?
  • Why are OSS/BSS important?
  • All about ACTI TVRO Antennas.
  • All about Althos Ad Insertion.
  • All about VOD from Edgeware.
infowins.description: Monitors and controls the status of signals, devices, and facilities.
infowins.title: Regional Operations Center
infowins.name: Regional_Operations_Center

infowins.html: Power modules (power packs) are replaceable and vary in form factor depending on vendor and amplifier model.
infowins.description: Converts AC to regulated DC in order to power the electronics.
infowins.title: Regulated Power Module
infowins.name: Regulated_Power_Module

infowins.html:
Learn more...
  • Are there different types of combiners?
  • What frequencies are used?
infowins.description: Combines the RF feeds from the QAM modulators, CMTS, and other RF equipment.
infowins.title: RF Combiner
infowins.name: RF_Combiner

infowins.html:
Learn more...
  • Why do we bond to ground?
  • What options do we have for bonding to ground??
  • When do we use a MOCA filter?
infowins.description: Houses the physical interface between the drop and the customer's inside wire.
infowins.title: RF Demarc
infowins.name: RF_Demarc

infowins.html: The RFoG ONU acts as a mini-node, converting optical signals in the downstream for voice, video, and data into RF, to be carried over the customers inside wire to the cable modem, gateway, or set top box. In the upstream, the ONU converts RF into optical signals to be carried back to the hub or headend over the fiberoptic cable.
infowins.description: Serves as a mini-node in a FTTH demarc supporting RF over Glass (RFoG).
infowins.title: RFoG Optical Network Unit (ONU)
infowins.name: RFoG_Optical_Network_Unit_ONU_

infowins.html: A heat gun or torch is used to shrink the tubing
infowins.description: Protects hardline connectors from the elements.
infowins.title: Shrink Tube
infowins.name: Shrink_Tube

infowins.html:
Used aerially or in a pedestal. The splice case is available in a variety of sizes and configurations. Designed with fiberoptic cable slack, stored using the sno shoes, the case can be easily removed and placed in a splicing truck, out of the weather.
  • Commscope Splice Cases
infowins.description: Secures the fiber splices in a protective case.
infowins.title: Splice Case
infowins.name: Splice_Case

infowins.html:
Passively splits the downstream and combines the upstream RF signals at the customer location.
  • What are the losses through a splitter?
infowins.description: Splits and combines the RF signals to support multiple CPE devices.
infowins.title: Splitter
infowins.name: Splitter

infowins.html: Strand is stranded galvanized steel cable, available in 1/4", 5/16", and 3/8" diameters. Strand is also called messenger and is connected to utility poles. Strand can support thousands of pounds.
infowins.description: Attaches to utility poles to support aerial cable and electronics in the OSP.
infowins.title: Strand
infowins.name: Strand

infowins.html: Galvanized steel clamps are used on poles to secure the strand in place and are available in straight-through (shown) or corner pole (right angle).
infowins.description: Secures strand to pole or support
infowins.title: Strand Suspension Clamp
infowins.name: Strand_Suspension_Clamp

infowins.html: The RF signal received by the antenna is typically a modulated MPEG4 stream which has to be converted to an MPEG2 transport stream. The RF signal from the antenna is routed to a integrated receiver transcoder (IRT) for this process.
infowins.description: The TV Receive-only (TVRO) antenna receives programming from national networks at the headend.
infowins.title: TV Receive Only Dish
infowins.name: TV_Receive_Only_Dish

infowins.html: Taps are available in 2, 4, and 8 ports and in varying dB levels of attenuation.
infowins.description: Splits the downstream RF spectrum to multiple drop cables and combines the upstreams from the drops.
infowins.title: Tap
infowins.name: Tap

infowins.html: The IRD decodes the digital data from the satellite and rebuilds it into a signal compatible with other headend/hub processing equipment.
infowins.description: Converts the Integrated Receiver Decoder (IRD) output signal to a format that can be connected to the hub router and switch.
infowins.title: Transcoder
infowins.name: Transcoder

infowins.description: Demodulates the ASI and QAM transport streams so they can be checked for quality.
infowins.title: Transport Stream (TS) Analyzer
infowins.name: Transport_Stream_TS_Analyzer

infowins.html: WiFi thermostats are part of the growing trend in home automation.
infowins.description: Operates on the Internet of Things (IoT). May be configured, operated, and monitored over the internet.
infowins.title: WiFi Thermostat
infowins.name: WiFi_Thermostat

infowins.html: Also known as a Hotspot, the WiFi hub broadcasts multiple network names for use by mobile and fixed devices nearby. These hubs enable Internet access similar to a wireless router in the home.
infowins.description: Provides access to the Internet and to the carrier's private network using WiFi.
infowins.title: Wireless Hub
infowins.name: Wireless_Hub

infowins.description: Tightens and loosens seizure screws and used for general purposes where needed.
